content: in your blowfish theme configuration config/_default/params.toml uncomment the following values under the [article] section [article] ... showDateUpdated = true showAuthor = true showAuthorBottom = true showHero = true heroStyle = "background" # valid options: basic, big, background, thumbAndBackground layoutBackgroundBlur = true # only used when heroStyle equals background or thumbAndBackground ... go to your posts folder content/posts find an image from the internet or use your own image place the image inside content/posts directory with “feature” prefix if image name is “1234.png” then it must be “feature-1234.png” to make blowfish recognize it

content: Enable the ‚ÄúDocker Bearer Token Realm‚Äù in Nexus If this is not enabled, Nexus won’t accept Docker login requests. In the Nexus UI: Go to Security ‚Üí Realms On the right side (Available realms), find: Docker Bearer Token Realm Move it to the left (Active realms) using the > button Make sure it is above the Docker Token realm if both are active Click Save

install nexus
apt install openjdk-17-jdk wget tar unzip -y cd /opt wget https://download.sonatype.com/nexus/3/nexus-3.83.1-03-linux-x86_64.tar.gz tar -xvf nexus-3.83.1-03-linux-x86_64.tar.gz mv nexus-3.83.1-03 nexus chown -R nexus:nexus /opt/nexus chown -R nexus:nexus /opt/sonatype-work nvim /opt/nexus/bin/nexus change shebang from sh to bash
run_as_user=‘nexus’ create a systemd service
nvim /etc/systemd/system/nexus.service
add the following
[Unit] Description=nexus service After=network.target [Service] Type=forking LimitNOFILE=65536 ExecStart=/opt/nexus/bin/nexus start ExecStop=/opt/nexus/bin/nexus stop User=nexus Restart=on-abort [Install] WantedBy=multi-user.target start nexus
systemctl daemon-reexec systemctl daemon-reload systemctl enable nexus systemctl start nexus reboot next steps is to get admin password for nexus

Introduction # you can find the pipeline here
Hello guys! In this video, we’ll be building a complete CI/CD pipeline from the ground up. I’ll guide you through setting up and using a variety of powerful tools including Terraform, Proxmox, NixOS, Jenkins, SonarQube, Docker, Kubernetes, and many more.
[Display additional tools on screen.]
We’ll start by creating this pipeline from scratch, beginning with Infrastructure as Code. Using Terraform and Proxmox, we‚Äôll spin up our servers, then proceed to install essential tools such as Jenkins, Kubernetes, ArgoCD, SonarQube, Nexus, and monitoring solutions like Prometheus and Grafana.
Finally, we’ll deploy a sample application using the full pipeline.
This will be a multi-part tutorial series, so stay tuned for more!
Pipeline Showcase # This is the pipeline we’ll be building throughout this tutorial series. I’ve intentionally made it complex to maximize the learning experience. Throughout the setup, I‚Äôve gained a lot of valuable insights, and now, I‚Äôm excited to share that knowledge with you. My goal is to help you deepen your understanding and take your skills to the next level.
[start explaining pipeline from start to finish]
A Note For My Environment # Let me quickly explain my environment so you‚Äôre comfortable following along.
For this tutorial, I‚Äôll be using a special Linux distribution called NixOS. The reason I chose NixOS is because of its powerful package manager and overall stability. I’ll walk you through how to install packages and use some of its key features. However, if you prefer using another Linux distro like Arch or Debian, that‚Äôs perfectly fine. It won‚Äôt make a big difference. But If you’re on Windows or macOS, I won‚Äôt be covering the installation of tools on those systems, so you’ll need to handle that part on your own.
For my text editor, I’ll be using Emacs, but feel free to use VSCode or any other tool you‚Äôre comfortable with.
To manage my terminal sessions more efficiently, I‚Äôll be using tmux. It’s an essential tool for anyone who spends a lot of time in the terminal, as it allows you to manage multiple sessions within a single terminal window. Plus, it preserves your SSH connections even if you accidentally close the terminal. For this tutorial, I‚Äôll be using two tmux sessions: one for editing text and typing commands in Emacs, and another for managing SSH connections. Don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôll explain everything as we go to make it all crystal clear.
To help you follow along more easily, I‚Äôll also be running a tool called screenkey, which will display my keystrokes in the bottom right corner.
Code and Documentation # I want to make things as easy as possible for you. All the code and documentation from this series will be available in one place. Just head over to savolla.github.io/cortex, where you‚Äôll find my personal knowledge base. Click on the ‚ÄòVideos‚Äô section, find the video you‚Äôre watching, and you‚Äôll have access to all the code and resources.
In the next episode, we‚Äôll begin by installing Proxmox as a virtual machine and use Terraform to spin up our servers
title: Zero to Hero CICD Pipeline | Part 1

Iosevka is already narrow but IosevkaTerm is better as a terminal font and programming in general. More characters fit in a single line
;; font configuration (setq doom-font (font-spec :family "IosevkaTerm Nerd Font Mono" :size 24) doom-variable-pitch-font (font-spec :family "IosevkaTerm Nerd Font Mono" :size 24)) Theme # I’m a big fan of Gruvbox color scheme.
;; theme (setq doom-theme 'doom-gruvbox) But I don’t like the default low contrast background of it so I made the background more darker. This setting is also better to use if you use transparency in emacs

;;; thicken window separator (setq window-divider-default-right-width 2 window-divider-default-bottom-width 2) ;;; change color of separator (custom-set-faces! '(vertical-border :foreground "#877b75")) Line Wrapping # this gives me a little bit of headache because line wrapping also affects my vterm shell. I need to find a way (a hook maybe?) to disable this in vterm
(global-visual-line-mode t) ; enable line wrapping globally Some QoL Improvements # I really don’t like the “whole line highlighting” in my editor. it may improve visibility of the current position but I prefer brighter cursor colors like #00FF00 instead
